# Know Your App


## Multi-threading

::: {.panel-tabset}

### About

- `%*%` operator triggers BLAS
- BLAS is multithreaded (OpenMP)
- experiment with `OMP_NUM_THREADS`
- Setting `S = 3333, P = 60, C = 1, N = 1`

### Results 

<div style="font-size: 0.75em;">

| THREADS | RUNTIME | SPEEDUP | EFF.  |
|---------|---------|---------|-------|
| 1       | 47.5    | 1.0     | 1.000 |
| 2       | 23.9    | 2.0     | 0.993 |
| 4       | 16.0    | 3.0     | 0.742 |
| 8       | 10.4    | 4.5     | 0.568 |
| 16      | 8.2     | 5.8     | 0.363 |
| 32      | 6.4     | 7.4     | 0.232 |
| 48      | 5.8     | 8.2     | 0.171 |
| 64      | 5.7     | 8.4     | 0.131 |
| 96      | 6.3     | 7.6     | 0.079 |

</div>

### Graph

![Multi-threading experiment](img/scaling_omp_num_threads.png)

### Conclusion

We fix `OMP_NUM_THREADS=4`.

:::: {.callout-warning .fragment}
Not setting `OMP_NUM_THREADS` leads to massive oversubscription
::::

:::: {.callout-tip .fragment}
`OMP_NUM_THREADS` $\leq$ number of cores
::::

:::

## Varying `--nr-cores`

::: {.panel-tabset}

### About

- `OMP_NUM_THREADS=4`, `S=333`, and `P=60`
- What does `--nr-cores` do?

### `R` script

```{r}
# if number of cores is greater than 1, use parallel processing
if (opt$nr_cores > 1) {
    library(doParallel)
    # cl set<- makeCluster(opt$nr_cores)
    # registerDoParallel(cl)
    registerDoParallel(opt$nr_cores)
}
```

### Results

<div style="font-size: 0.75em;">

| NR_CORES | RUNTIME | SPEEDUP | EFF.  |
|---------|---------|---------|-------|
| 1       | 17.7    | 1.0     | 1.000 |
| 2       | 15.9    | 1.1     | 0.557 |
| 4       | 15.3    | 1.2     | 0.289 |
| 8       | 15.2    | 1.2     | 0.145 |
| 16      | 15.4    | 1.2     | 0.072 |
| 24      | 15.4    | 1.1     | 0.048 |

</div>

### Graph

![Using multiple cores](img/runtime_nr_cores.png)

### Conclusion

- Clearly, we are not exploiting this feature
- Relevant if `--nr_matrices > 1`
- We pass `--nr-cores=1`.

:::

## Optimal Setup for the Baseline

- `export OMP_NUM_THREADS=4`
- `P = 60`
- `C = 1`
- `M = 1`
- To mimic different domain sizes: $S \in [3000 : 5000]$.
